description.text:
This is a rework of thing:1596627 - 7849 Three Piece Puzzles. It is an attempt to make 3 piece puzzles which are more difficult to solve. Instead of 3 pieces of equal size the pieces are now of three different sizes. This increases the number of possible puzzles. Three puzzles are included here:

puzzle_p8910_21062.stl
puzzle_p8910_21074.stl
puzzle_p8910_28770x.stl

OpenSCAD code which is capable of constructing 45972 different puzzles is included.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

All the puzzles overhang and need support.

A number of puzzles were constructed in a search for more difficult ones. Two of the included puzzles slide together easily and depend on the complexity of the pieces to confuse the solver. Puzzle_p8910_28770x.stl is actually physically insolvable. Clearances were increased by 50% which allows it to be solved. The piece of 10 subcubes takes a path around the 3x3x3 cube and if the piece containing 9 subcubes is inserted in the right position it can be rotated into position with little or no resistance. More details are given at the beginning of the openSCAD code.
This is the Mantis 9.1 designed by David Carr at MIT. It is a mini mill that people have built for less than 100 dollars. It seems to be best at pcb engraving and other semi hard materials.

http://www.youtube.com/user/therealdcarr/videos Here are a set of videos That David posted. I reccommend watching all of them before starting. I did make 1 change: I changed the "tap yourself" acme nuts to a McMaster steel nut. I did use a cheap part. I did this because the ACME tap kit I found for this cost around 200 dollars. I'm looking forward to seeing what other people do with this design. I will be building it at FabLab Tulsa. I'll keep adding files as I make more progress. Feel free to request things, I hope I can help. It looks like the original site has been moved here: http://makeyourbot.org/mantis9-1

A snug fitting case for the Raspberry Pi with screw board mounts and a snap top. This case is designed to fit the Raspberry Pi Model B+, Pi 2 Model B, and Pi 3 Model B. HATs may be installed over the top of the case. The top comes in four versions - cooling slots and connector openings, cooling slots only, connector openings only, and with no slots or openings.

There are two holes on both sides of the front to view the two LEDs on the Pi board since the Pi 3 has the LEDs on the opposite side as the other models. The micro SD is easily removed with a curved card entry on the bottom of the case.

The standoffs for the Pi board are designed for #2 x 1/4" thread rolling screws.

For the Arduino Uno, see the Arduino Uno Snug Case.

For the Arduino Mega, see the Arduino Mega Snug Case.

I am merely providing you with a tool to generate an infinite array of unique, and strangely Dali-esque, cactii models. What you choose to do with that information is up to you.

For more information about growing your own unique foliage using OpenSCAD, please check out my Instructable at http://www.instructables.com/id/Procedurally-Generated-Trees/

(There's still a few days left to vote for it in the 3D printing Instructables contest!)

If you just want to make a unique cactus in Customizer without worrying about the nitty gritty details, just know that the most important variable to change is the seed. The seed determines what pseudo-random values are chosen and thus the overall shape of your cactus.
Lay the wings flat to allow printing without support.
I added 3/4 to each side of the cross slide base to increase stability and a few other modifications to increase rigidity and ease of casting.

author: MiguelPynto

description.text: Sphero, the Bluetooth controlled robotic ball, is not only a super cool toy, but also a powerful way to introduce students to the basics of programming thanks to visual programming language. Take your classroom Sphero time to the next level by challenging students to designing their own obstacles to navigate into, around, and over!

I used Tinkercad to design the example due to it's ease of use, no cost, and since it is browser based. Furthermore, I have had luck teaching students as young as seven how to use Tinkercad, making it well suited for use in elementary classrooms.
NGSS

Sphero is a great way for students as young as five to lay the foundation of understanding coding in an engaging, physical way. However, just ambling around the classroom can get a little dull. With this lesson you not only encourage the need for more advanced programming to navigate an obstacle course, you'll also introduce students to another valuable skill- desktop fabrication! Objectives Students will gain basic design and 3-D printing knowledge to create items for a Sphero obstacle course. In turn, students will use visual or syntax coding languages to navigate Sphero successfully through the obstacle course they create as a class. Subjects
  • Design
  • Engineering
  • Coding
    • Skills Learned (Standards) Third Grade: NGSS: 3-5-ETS1-1, 3-5-ETS1-3

• Open the lesson by navigating a Sphero around the classroom, preferably around and under desks and chairs, highlighting the challenges of navigating obstacles.
  • Task students to create a series of obstacles that will be used to create a course they will later navigate Sphero through.
  • Assign students (or student team) to brainstorm and sketch their obstacle idea(s).
  • Students then map the classroom and diagram where their obstacle be located.
  • Introduce Tinkercad (or the design program of your choice) to the class, guiding them through the basics of it's use. Encourage creativity, making recommendations if students get stuck when generating ideas, such as tunnels, ramps, speed bumps, or bridges. Given the sometimes grand scope of student imaginations it is important to define maximum obstacle dimensions which match the capability of your printer. This will also add an additional engineering challenge as students will have to consider a preset restraint on their designs.
  • Encourage students to design, print, test, and redesign their obstacles as time and resources allow.
  • Create the complete obstacle course as a class, preferably in a way that allows it to remain in place for serval days.
  • Students practice programming Sphero through the obstacle course, assessing the creativity, challenge, and design of each obstacle. If possible, allow students to take feed back from classmate assessments and redesign their obstacle.
    • Extension Have the class design obstacles which physically connect and/or trigger one another in Rube Goldberg fashion. OR, since Sphero is waterproof, why not include a water obstacle!?!
5-10 sessions

Ideally students will begin this lesson with some skill in programming Sphero. This knowledge will give them a better idea of the types of obstacles Sphero can feasibly navigate. However, this project can include programming as one of it's goals, but additional time should be allotted.

Each student (or student team) must design and print a fully usable obstacle course element by lesson's end. A possible rubric addressing both creativity and design can be found above with the thing files.

Check out Sphero Education (http://www.sphero.com/education) for more information and ideas on the many ways Sphero can be used in the classroom.
In need of some real life obstacle course inspiration? Take a look at the page included with the thing files above, that or watch a few clips from Wipe Out! Handouts & Assets If not already available, download the SPRK Lab app (iOS, Android, and FireOS) to begin programming your classroom Sphero before, during, and after the lesson.

description.text: The original is a phenomenal mount (shout-out to mming1106) but I needed to screw it to the face of my CNC and while there were other mounts with tabs for screws, I liked the way this fits and how the board is screwed onto the supports, so the right thing was to contribute a remixed version with tabs for screws that can be reached while the board is mounted and even with the RAMPS on. Aimed to make my mods true to the original design.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Nothing fancy - design is very print friendly.

From original to remix...

I modified the original STL using FreeCAD and I've uploaded the FreeCAD file for the convenience of anyone else that needs a mod to make it just right. Remember to attribute this back to mming1106 who gave us this great design.

I think I've hit a bug in FreeCAD 0.16 that made it necessary to do a cut instead of a union to join the original and the tabs! So when you use the file in a later version it might goof up and require some rework. If anyone sees this, let me know and I'll try again and see if I can get it working.

comments.text: So I ran into the same issue with the torso and the chest.. and for me unfortunately netfab wasn't the solution the combining of those pieces without actually doing a boolean-weld (thats what I'd use in Cinema 4D to get these to work, however Im rendering something out in c4d so I couldn't use it.) make my slicer see them as hollow pieces where they intersect. Im using Simplify3D. But I did find a solution in Simplify3D. Under Mesh select "separate connected meshes" and it splits the part into its original pieces and then if you print all those as 1 job they combine together properly.

This is a wire mount for a 2020 aluminum rail. It is designed to be bolted down by an M4 x 10 mm bolt. I looped a 1/16th cable wire through the hole to cross brace my FLSUN Delta printer/s frame.

I heated the M4 bolt before putting it in the hole. The hole in the design is very sung, but thats what I wanted. Holding the bolt under a lighter for a few seconds should allow the M4 bolt to screw in easily.

The STL is oriented the way I installed the part but when I printed it I oriented the part like a D so the printer layers were vertical to improve the strength of the part.

Before you make your round lock pick, consider its rectangular sister model. You might perfer that one, you might prefer this one. Up to you.

This round lock pick generator can make an infinite number of different lock pick shapes. Triangle? Sure! Square? Why not! Rounded? You bet! Its up to you!

This is for home made picks and for purchased sets like the South Ord PHX-17 which features a interchangeable handle and many picks you screw into the handle.

With this file you'll be able to print handles for virtually any pick that needs one.

You're gonna need a pair of calipers to measure your pick(s). If you're going for a press fit don't forget about the various limiting factors; filament accuracy/warp, printer accuracy. I print mine vertically to avoid the subtle sag of bridging. You might want to fudge the number and use a little glue. Again, this is up to you.

print_settings.Notes:: CHEERS!!

description.text:
Created by popular demand!

The Airbus A320 family consists of narrow-body, commercial airliners manufactured by Airbus. The family includes the A318, A319, A320 and A321, as well as the ACJ business jet, which I do not intend to model. The A320s are also named A320ceo (current engine option) after the introduction of the A320neo. After a few weeks of hiatus from modeling, I am planning on adding the A320neo package on as a quick print, which the primary upgrade being the engines.

I have traditionally stayed away from modeling Airbus aircraft. Aside from the fact that I have not flown on the Airbus to the extent I have on Boeing products, I disagree with the Airbus cockpit design. Such a reliance on automation does relieve a considerable amount of crew workload, yet opens the risk of complacency and the loss of stick and rudder skills. I could go on about this subject (and have written term papers on it) but that's for another venue.

This model was the first one to be built with intermeshing parts based on the Aircraft model, instead of simple pegs and slots. The foreward and aft portions of the fuselage are varied in size based on your desired model. As the A320 family is designed to be very similar across all platforms, indeed the centerbody, wings, engines, nose and tail are all the same (with the exception of the tail height on the A318). This will allow you to print once and customize whichever model you prefer. This also made designing it a breeze, as all four aircraft were built simultaneously, thanks to the components feature of Sketchup (although this did take some experimenting with in order to ensure the parts were scaled accurately to the real model). This model has been in the works for a month now, as it was caught in the middle of a big move down to Florida.

As always, if you have any questions let me know!

Version 1.0.0

Step 2: Print whichever model you would prefer (A318set etc.) to get the fuselage components, which vary by model number.

Inspired by ChaoticAtmospheres on DeviantArt--is a model of the Aizawa Attractor, a chaotic attractor. Produced in Mathematica. Mathematica code given below. Have never tried to print this--please let me know of your experiences.

beta = 0.7;
eps = 0.25;
alph = 0.95;
del = 3.5;
gam = 0.6;
chi = 0.1;

Timing[soln = NDSolve[{
x'[t] == (z[t] - beta)x[t] - dely[t],
y'[t] == delx[t] + (z[t] - beta)y[t],
z'[t] ==
gam + alphz[t] - ((z[t])^3)/
3 - ((x[t])^2 + (y[t])^2)(1 + epsz[t]) + chiz[t]*(x[t])^3,
x[0] == z[0] == .1,
y[0] == 0
}, {x, y, z}, {t, 0, 200}, MaxSteps -> Infinity]]

plot = ParametricPlot3D[
Evaluate[{x[t], y[t], z[t]} /. soln], {t, 0, 200}, PlotRange -> All,
PlotStyle -> Tube[.05, PlotPoints -> 100], Ticks -> None]

Export["aizawa.stl", plot]

A tribute to Ethan Klein's satire of vaporizer culture. This is pendant designed to be part of a chain or necklace. Two versions are available. Pictured is the open finger version, where the left index finger only touches the right ring fin ger knuckle. The other version depicts the left index and right middle fingers almost parallel.

Disclaimer: I do not support smoking or vaping of any kind.

Kerrby

Orient it so it with either the palms or the backs of the hands facing down. Be careful of narrow support structures that might be unstable on your machine.

This was designed using free model-generating software. The model was then imported into blender and one hand was posed into a piece sign. I then chopped the model up and used Meshmixer to reduce the polygon count. Finally I meticulously cleaned up the low-poly model in Rhino. Rhino was then used to arrange the hands, add some support, and add a loop for a chain.

My doors have a design flaw; the hinges are metal, but they are attached to the door with a brittle piece of plastic. When you use a powered wheelchair like I (and my late wife), it's easy to accidentally hit the door and break the plastic. To make things worse, I haven't been able to find replacements? So, instead of staging a hunt for the spare part, I made a copy in Fusion 360 and printed it in strong PETG plastic.

description.text:
This is improved from my original version http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1243507

It is not a remix but a completely new design done in Fusion 360.

The shape has been made as close to a classic Incandescent C9 bulb as possible.

The base features a 13mm thread that will screw down over the soft plastic surrounding common LED Pixels used in Christmas lights. I have tested this on quite a few different pixels I have and it provides a secure fit that is far less likely to come off than the original push fixture.

The shell is 0.8mm thick in the design aimed at two perimeters using a 0.4mm nozzle.

Three STL's are provided, one is a classic smooth exterior and the others features random facets that give an external texture but don't really change the light too much

C9bulbnew........Smooth
C9bulbnew-f..... very light facets
C9bulbnew-f2..... light facets

You could print in translucent colours for white leds.

Printer:

FlashForge Pro Dual

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm or 0.1mm

Notes:

Translucent ABS works really well for these.

I print these exclusively sliced with S3D using 3 processes, one for the base, one for the main section and one for the top 20 layers.

I print the top 20 layers at 0.1mm to ensure a nice water tight finish though 0.2mm should be fine.

comments.text:
I had seen your 3D session in one of the Aussie Mini videos a while back and just recently got a MP Mini Delta so I have to try these. This year will be my first RGB Christmas so I'm still in early learning mode, but I hope you might have the time to help. I noticed on your original design you talked about having a brim otherwise a raft is nearly mandatory. I have S3D and still just getting my feet wet with it, but for this design I don't need a brim or raft? Because I do have S3D, could you explain what how you had your three processes configured. I just have the one process defined and until I read your details, never thought of adding more. I want the bulbs to come out as you intended. Note sure if I'll have time to print enough to use for this Christmas, but your design fits in perfect with my learning RGB and 3D, so thank you very much.
Greg

title: Zortrax air evac fan holder – IN PROGRESS

description.text:
(Edit: I will from time to time publish updates under the headline "How I designed this")

Liking the look of ABS prints, but not so much the smell and the sore throat that comes with being exposed to the fumes for long periods? Well, you and me both. So I have bought a quiet 140 mm computer case fan, a metre and a half of ventilation tube, and designed a fan holder that can be hung over the left or right edge of a Zortrax m200 3d printer. It's a 17 hour print (crossing my fingers that I didn't mess up the model...), and it has some 9+ hours left.

(A note, my hope is that the position of the fan does not affect the quality of the prints, I've printed a torture test model before the fan, and will do that again with the fan on 100% power.)

Update 2016-06-22, **facepalm**

Simple question to self: If you buy a 140 mm (remember that figure) case fan, and the closest size ventilation hose is 130 mm, then it stands to reason that you design an adapter/holder to fit those figures, right? Then how come the printed adapter is a perfect fit, except for the external dimension of the square flange, that turns out to be exactly 150.0 mm? 100 grams of PETG, and 17 hours of print time. I'm not printing that again because I am a [insert your favourite word here] who gets the easy parts wrong... So, uploading a new fastener model shortly, as well as a correct adapter. :P

(later...)

If you haven't printed the models yet, get the ones that say "140mm"...

Fastener models removed!

Yesterday I tested the fume evacuation fan, and it didn't work quite as expected... It did remove the smell to a high degree, but the extruder head hugs the edge of the printer's top opening so closely that it snags the fasteners... Back to the drawing board, I'll probably make a version with neodymium magnets...

description.text:
This is a stand for tips of an electrical toothbrush of Braun/Oral B.
We had a toothbrush stand, but it was designed for normal toothbrushes, hence it was to deep to fit the tips in. 
So I designed this stand that fits nicely and that can hold 4 tips.

Print, install and use.
You might want to adapt the base of the stand to fit your situation, or make it even wider so that it can be used stand alone.
Depending on how well-tuned your printer is, the tip inserts of the stand might require light sanding so that the tips easily come off when you need them.

title: M12 extruder bolt or axle hobbing tool

description.text:
Tool that will help make 12mm hobbed bolt or axle for a filament.

BOM

Printable:

  • hobbing tool 1pc

Hardware:

  • DIN 618 hk1210 bearings 2pcs

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25

Notes:

230C hotend

100C heatbed

15 lines brim

Clean.

Press-fit bearings.

Clamp in a vice.

Insert bolt or axle with dredging, fix with nuts.

Insert M3 tap into electric drill or screw with adjustable rpms.

Apply drilling oil on dredging and tap. Actually, any liquid oil will do, but machine or special drilling are best choice.

Don't do this without oil. You'll definitely screw things up.

Hold drill perpendicular to an axle.

Push drill harder to the left, as it'll try to escape to the right.

Start drilling on as low rpms as possible.

Hold the drill tightly on the same place so that axle to rotate steadily. Otherwise, some notches will be deeper than others.

Continue, sometimes cleaning the dredging and tap and applying more oil.

Repeat till axle will make few complete revolutions.

Verify results visually. If somewhere notches are not deep enough, tap that single area by slowly pushing drill forward while drilling.

After crafting two axles, bearings most likely should be thrown away, or kept for hobbing only.
They should not be used somewhere due to metal chip that will definitely get inside.

comments.text: Sorry to hear you having trouble printing this.I printed it with no supports ,10% infill no problems ,I just ran it through Makerbot print,shows it will take about 8hrs to print on these settings,and 8hrs 15mins at 20%,All I can suggest is because it takes so long to print you could take the file into meshmixer ,cut off a slice horizontally ,so you are not printing the whole file and try printing with different infill.You will find that because of the way 3d printing prints in layers,( like a horizontal grain ) printing objects like this can be fragile,some filament is better for this than others. Regards Clive.

Slap some windows and a door onto an old cereal box to upcycle it into a toy. Use the brackets to attach windows and doors to a cereal box - or really anything that is made of cardboard. The two blue kids were printed from scans made by The Great Fredini's Scan-A-Rama. (Sorry, but those files aren't included - just the house elements.)

Print out all the pieces. You can just wing it and cut a bunch of holes, but I provided stencils for the windows and doors to use as a guide for making the holes. I recommend an xacto knife for cutting out the windows. You can, of course, just cut the holes for the brackets. I like leaving them open as it gives it a sense of depth. More pictures are over on my [blog]( http://dadhoc.com/2013/11/cereal-box-brownstone/).

These are supports for the card barrier in the third edition of the great board-game Catacombs by Elzra.

title: Customizable Name/Registration Plate Keyring
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Customisable name tag or registration plate keyring.

Simply customise, print and attach to your car keys and never worry about remembering your reg, or which keys to pick up, again.

I'm fairly experienced in SolidWorks, but new to OpenSCAD. I originally designed this for myself in SolidWorks, but I thought this design would benefit from being customizable, so I gave it a bash. Please let me know if there's anything I can change to improve my code! I cheated with the geometry and used an STL to OpenSCAD converter courtesy of Riham (thanks).

My original design used a free non-standard font (REGISTRATION PLATE UK.ttf) which I'm not sure is possible to embed. Any advice and feedback greatly appreciated!

Update 24/06/16: Added solidworks model. To customise in solidworks, create a 'New Derivied Configuration' using your text as the description. You may need to install a new font or tweak the size to suit.

author: properbowen

description.text:
We needed a towel hanger for 4 towels in our bathroom. Existing towel hangers didn't match what we needed, so I designed one myself.
The hanger consists of 'clamps' that can be attached to the wall. They hold round metal bars that I scavenged from an old towel rack we had.
This was my first experiment in making a larger real-world object that would need to pass the test of my family. Up to now, it is still going strong :-)

Obtain round metal bars of the required length. The diameter of the rods I used is 16 mm. Adjust the hole size in the stl if required.
Print 1 towel_hanger_v1 (I used 2 outer shells and 20% infill, printed in PLA). This is the central part with holes in both sides. The bars fit snugly in this part. Press the bars in the clamp before mounting it to the wall.
Print 1 towel_hanger_left and one towel_hanger_right with the same settings. Those parts only have holes for the bars in one side.
Drill holes, I only drilled one hole and used a 8 mm plug with a long screw. The parts have two mounting holes, you can use both but then you need to use a smaller diameter plug (as the holes are quite close to each other).
The holes in the _left and _right part are slightly larger than the holes in the center part to ease the mounting. Should the bars only fit loosely, insert a small rubber strip between the bar and the clamp.
Print 3 'plugs' to cover the mounting holes. A small amount of sanding might be required to let the plug fit nicely in the mounting hole of the clamp. 
Then, print the 'knijpers' (clips) to clip towels to the bars. 
'Personalized' clips for the kids are a win, now they are eager to hang their towels themselves...
AWESOME

title: Cubify 3D Sense holder for Surface pro 3 and 4

description.text:
I made this because I wand to scan larger things, without the USB-cable to get in the scan and it was hard to start and stop the scan by pressing the button with my nose.

Instructions:

  1. Print
  2. Slide the Scanner in and secure it with a 1/4" Screw (alt.: cable-ties)
  3. Tie the USB-cable to the holder's leash and slide it through the square opening (there is an option to screw the connector in place with a M4 screw)

Compatibility:

  • Microsoft Surface Pro 3
  • Microsoft Surface Pro 4 (needs a cloth to strengthen the grip)
  • 3DSystems Cubify 3D-Sense

Benefits:

  • one-handed operation without clutter (leaves other hand free to start and stop the scan on the tablet)
  • comfortable (though heavy)

comments.text: I am considering a four-finger pistol grip formed around the camera-mounting screw.  The Surface Pro 2 and 4 that I am trying to mount generation 1 (Win8.1) and generation 2 (Win 10) Sense3D scanners to are slippery devils!  And you need a free hand throughout.

title: Extruder E3D type bowden coupler clip shim

description.text:
This is a remixed version of the extruder multi clip but smaller to suit the E3D bowden locking ring fitting. This prevents the locking ring from moving in and out of the extruder/hotend which prevents poor filament control especially when retracting/unretracting.

Slide the clip into place before inserting the bowden tube and you'll have a tight fit with no play from the start. Unclip it to remove your bowden tube.

I used Tinkercad to design this.
for test printing

title: Lewihe Play 3D bowden layer fan blower

description.text:
Pics shows how this part fits in the whole design (blue part). The part that fits the LM6UU bearings is the Play3D original part. Other parts conform my custom design for the Play3D's X-Carriage.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1547122
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1527259
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1639559

and also used this awesome 40mm fan model for reference: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:32246

My previous design of a layer fan for this extremely small hotend used a 30mm fan but this one is much better. I know this little fans very well, and as I thought it started to have troubles after just a month of printing (24/7). I mean it started to be noisy, and thus, prone to fail soon. I have thinking about this for two weeks and I have decided to bring in a new solution. Well, I can't put in that little room a larger fan, but I can use a cheap vinyl or silicone tube from anywhere out of the printer where I have free space, using this tube as an air conduct I can manage to use a durable and powerful 50mm blower instead of a #&$#%# little fan, and have lots of air pressure when needed. Besides this, the air coming from the exterior part of the printer is cooler and works better. This little part of just 44x24mm will do the job. Just use a ~8mm inner diameter tube, attach it to the part, fix it with some ties and job done. At first I thought about using a PTFE tube and pneumatic fittings but that was an expensive solution and less flexible. Use your own solution to attach the blower where you want, or use the one included. Print the part in ABS with buildplate support only, don't use complete support as it will completely clog the air flow, and you won't be able to remove the inner support, remember this is a hollow part. Bridging should be ok. V2 new version recommended.

TODO: Nothing. Performs as expected.

UPDATE (29-JUN-2016):V2 enhanced M3 bolt support. Reinforced latch. I ended breaking the bolt support when tightening. Shortened back 4mm the bolt support length, 30mm M3 bolts weren't enough. Some minor design changes. This a final version (if that exists). Previous versions will not be maintained.

UPDATE (28-JUN-2016): V2 added. Increased screw length to use a 30mm M3 regular screw. Added a latch to avoid pitching, this also helps ABS printing acting as as extra cooling pillar. Removed unnecessary material that could interfere with bed clips. Rounded and refined design. Increased air output hole to enhance airflow. Added a small duct to aim better the airflow. Part still requires buildplate support ONLY, and only due to the tube connector, any other overhang angle is 45º or more. Will put pics when I have the time. First version works fine but some improvements should be done. You don't need to update your printed part if it works well for your setup, but if you do you won't regret. Anyway no more updates expected for this part beyond this V2.

UPDATE (22-JUN-2016): Updated model and STL for a inner ~8mm tube, The only one I could find nearby as I ended all my 6mm tube stocks. Lengthened a bit the part to accomodate the 8mm inner / 10mm outer diameter tube. Anyway performing even better than previous model as the airflow is enhanced by the greater diameter of the tube.

title: RADDS case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
RADDS case

I created this case for the heavily modified C-Bot/D-Bot style CoreXY machine that I'm currently building. It has a large number of modified and custom parts. This is one of them.
I'm publishing this case now, because it is not machine specific (aside from the 20mm extrusion mounting tabs).

Features:

Dual fans and side exhaust vents.
Full width access slot to the Power Input and MOSFET Output terminal block.
Right side slot for misc wires - endstops, thermistors, display, etc.
Precisely located holes and slots for the RADDS SD card and reset button, Due USB ports and power input connector.
Mounting tabs to allow attachment to 20mm extrusions with up to 5mm screws.
Slots to allow a small screwdriver to be inserted to pry the RADDS board from the Due board for easier disassembly.

Modeled in SpaceClaim.

Update. V3 lid provides more headroom for the fans so that the wires don't press up against them.

Printer:

Custom Kossel 2020

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

200 micron

Notes:

Will definitely need support under the long terminal block slot and probably the right side wiring slot. I also used supports under the SD slot, USB slots and power connector hole, but those are your choice.
Print lid top face down.
Board standoffs and walls were optimized to be printed with a 0.4mm nozzle and 0.48mm extrusion width. (Auto extrusion width setting in Simplify 3D). I recommend using an M3 tap to thread all holes for the M3 screws.
The RADDS and Due boards can not be inserted into the case when plugged together. First install the DUE board, insert screws, then drop the RADDS board in place and seat it. Check the access holes to verify the RADDS board is fully seated.

description.text:
This was a design I mocked up to cover the front of the BeeRotor X200 to stop grass and water etc getting in so easily. It isn't perfect but it works. I have the hole in the front set for my flight controller USB which is at that height because it is setup with standoffs, PDB, standoffs then the SPR F3 FC on top. There is a cut out at bottom of the front part that allows for the routing of the ESC cables into the main body of the quad.
I have attached a before an after photo of my quad with this on...

This part matches up nicely with my HS1177 camera mount for the X200 to cover the front of the quad and mount the camera securely.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1568906

Fitting:
There are two holes in the sides of the frame and the two 'lugs' on the part fit in these two holes. The fitment is tight and pushes against my custom HS1177 camera mount above. If you are using the stock carbon camera mount I don't know if this part would fit or not, likely it would if you have the camera mount with the little bump upwards but I can't guarantee it because I don't use it at all.

Wanhao Duplicator i3

0.1-0.2

Infill:

100%

Print flat, or on it's side it doesn't matter really but both will require supports. I find printing flat with supports gives a nice finish for the front, the back has support marks but you can't see it anyway.

title: Yet another Raspberry Pi Camera mount (pinoir v2)

description.text:
EDIT: 2016-06-30

After some use, the joints has worn out a bit, so its not as tight as before, I've uploaded a new version which is a bit "thicker". I ended up gluing the joint when I got it aligned as I wanted. Its not my best design, be aware of this, a quick way to get the raspi camera up though.

I needed a way to mount my Raspberry Pi PiNoIr v2 onto my Raspberry Case.
I dont want to use other hardware like bolts and nuts if possible because I never have things like that at home when I need it, so I designed my own. That can be assembled and used as printed with two "ball-type" joints.

This arm I glued onto the Raspberry case, which is standing just next to my Original Prusa i3 MK2, and now with the camera overlooking the printbed.

I added holes to actually mount the camera with screws if you want to but it fits perfectly so its not needed. Also the back is just snapped on and stays there due to really small tolerances, it dosnt fall off, but if you want it to really stay in place or if you're using the mount on a Quadcopter or similar, or if your printer is underextruding you might want to use a rubber band or similar to hold the back-plate in place.

This is a printable roller chain. Once the segment is printed, it is operational. You can also easily break any link, or add additional links.

Do not use supports, but I tend to use rafts. It will work without a raft, but I found it creates a curve to the chain.

I have included the solidworks models so you can make the chain as long as you want. I usually keep it relatively short. That way, if the build fails, I don't lose hours of printing. Individual segments can be joined together after printing. Finally, make sure the chain is laying flat so that the pivot axes are parallel to the print bed.

With ratio 1:2
The bevel gear and pinion parameters, it's calculated and determined from:
http://www.daycounter.com/Calculators/Bevel-Gear-Calculator.phtml

description.text:
A friend requested a print of a modified version of the original design ( Nanna-Sin Ziggurat by PirateMaster11 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1457174 ). In general, the design was modified a bit, scaled down and split in pieces to enable large size printing.

Images taken with a potato. Apologies.

(The design for gargoyle is not present but it is just for decorative purposes.)

Printer:

Kossel XL

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

With the present settings (2 perimeters, 2 floor layers, 4 top layers) it takes around 250m 1.75mm filament. 3 perimeters might be better for the stairs.

Modifications made with Blender to the original design:

1) Base removed
2) Model scaled down. Base of the main building is now 22x22cm (scaled down to: X = 0.675, Y = 0.645, Z = 0.660). Total printed size is about 33x22x11 cm.
3) The walls were modified flat to remove the slight hint of middle ages.
4) Model chopped in 6-7 pieces (depending whether you print the front yard in 1 or 2 pieces). Largest part is 1-piece front yard (up to 22cm) and 2nd largest part is right side of the 2-piece front yard (up to 13cm).
5) 2mm holes punched on the matching pairs for easier assembly.

author: sebureau

print_settings.Notes::
For extruder body and clamp plate, you'd better choose version with integrated support.
Generating support with slicer will affect the brim, so wrapping may become fatal.
Also, slicer-generated support is harder to get rid of.

description.text:
Developed to extrude 3mm (2.85mm) filament via E3D hotend.

Can be modified to use 1.75mm filament by making appropriate hobbed axles.

X carriage mounting bolts offset 24mm

Design goals:

  • improve extrusion accuracy;
  • improve extrusion stability;
  • improve filament reaction;
  • increase filament pressure;
  • decrease filament slipping possibility;
  • increase retraction accuracy;
  • increase X-axis available print length;
  • provide easier maintenance;
  • improve attachement to X-carriage;
  • achieve low weight;
  • provide cable management;

Pros:

  • extrusion is very accurate (+/- 1mm calibration on 100mm extrusion);
  • very stable results even under pressure (important for first layer on non-planar heatbeds);
  • very accurate retraction due to almost no backlash;
  • high maximum filament pressure due to bigger hobbed axle diameter and two hobbed axles;
  • filament is more responsive due to reduction of length between hobbed axle and nozzle;
  • extruder stepper motor not crossing Z threaded rod on the left side, so X homing point can be moved to the left (I was able to reach 216mm X by 206 mm Y print area after some heatbed modification);
  • designed to be easily opened to change filament / cleanup;
  • remembers filament hold-down tension setting;
  • gears and hobbed axles can be removed with no tools (nuts can be placed, but are redundant);
  • places for zip-ties to get cables in place.
  • really lightweight (for dual extruder) due to hk1210 bearing usage for hobbed axles. With aluminium axles only 90 grams heavier than Wade's extruder;
  • no need to center drive gear;
  • more steadily attached to X-carriage due to bigger attachment plane.

Cons:

  • parts are not easily-printed, especially extruder body and clamp plate;
  • lots of work to remove supportive structures from body and clamp plate;
  • lathe required to craft hobbed axles;
  • some parts are not easy to obtain (M3x50 bolts, M2 threaded rod);
  • Y axis print area moves 10-15mm towards Ymax (can be fixed by Y-axis calibration).

BOM

printables:

  • extruder body 1pc
  • drive gear 1pc
  • big driven gear 1pc
  • small driven gear 1pc
  • clamp plate 1pc
  • latch 1pc
  • latch fixer axle 1pc
  • latch fixer axle knob 1pc

hardware:

  • DIN 618 hk1210 bearings 4pcs
  • DIN 625 skf 608 bearings 2pcs
  • bolt DIN 912 M3x50 3pcs
  • bolt DIN 912 M3x45 2pcs
  • bolt DIN 912 M3x14 4pcs
  • setup screw DIN 913 M8x30 2pcs
  • setup screw DIN 914 M3x6 1pc
  • screw DIN 84 M2x12 1pc
  • nut DIN 934 M3 4pcs
  • nut DIN 934 M2 5pcs
  • washer DIN 125 M3 6pcs

either

  • bolt DIN 931 M12x80 1pc
  • bolt DIN 931 M12x100 1pc

or

  • hobbed axle 12x72 1pc
  • hobbed axle 12x94 1pc
  • nut DIN 439 M12 2pcs

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25-50

Notes:
  • 230C hotend
  • 100C heatbed
  • 1 line shell thickness
  • 20-25 lines of brim for big details.

    As of infill, for most details 25% will do.
    But for extruder body, I've got a little wrapping.
    It is not critical, but 40-50% infill will hopefully do better.
    For gears with small teeth (drive gear and big driven gear) I used slow speed for outer shell (not more than 10-20mm/min).

For extruder body and clamp plate, you'd better choose version with integrated support.
Generating support with slicer will affect the brim, so wrapping may become fatal.
Also, slicer-generated support is harder to get rid of.

For small driven gear you'd choose regular version.
The one with deeper nut hollow required only if you're going to lock hobbed axle with DIN 985 M12 lock-nut.

For small driven gear and big driven gear you should use support to nicely print bolt plane.

Cleaning

Remove supportive structures carefully.
Most attention to 608 bearings inner race supports in extruder body and clamp plate.
These supports are 0.7 mm thick, so it is about 3 layers. They should not be damaged.

Other places to take care are:

  • 608 bearings outer shell (clean it nicely for bearing outer race not to touch it);
  • 608 bearings rod dredging (clean printing artifacts, if any or else you'll have problems pushing rod inside);
  • Holes for latch on the top of extruder body (clean it inside for latch to move steadily within 35 degrees;
  • Hotend mount slot;
  • Big driven gear teeth (some artifacts may occur near bottom of the gear, near the root of a tooth);
  • Space between latch tensioners on a clamp plate (it should be enough for the latch fixer axle to pass freely);
  • Deepenings for M12 nuts on big and small driven gears.

Filament hole should be drilled with 3.2mm drill bit.
All M3 bolt holes (hotend mounting, clamp plate mounting, extruder to X-carriage mounting, motor mounting) should be drilled with 3mm drill bit if M3 bolt is not fitting right away.
For M2 bolt/axles use 2mm drill bit.

Hobbed axles

To craft bolts or axles you need lathe at least to make filament groove.
Hobbed bolt can be crafted using either
DIN 931 M12 bolt
or
Metal hex blank.

Hobbed axle can be crafted out of aluminium blank and turned into bolt using either
DIN 439 M12 nut (low profile for low weight)
or
DIN 985 lock nut with nylon.

To decrease weight both bolts and axles can be drilled inside according to blueprints.

After filament groove in bolt or axle is done, hobs are applied using M3 tap, M12 bolt hobbing tool, 2x hk1210 bearings, slow-speed electric screw or drill and a vice.
When using this method of hobbing, care to buy 2 extra hk1210 bearings, as they would become useless for extruder due to metal chip.

To convert hobbed axle into hobbed bolt, I used

  • lathe-crafted aluminium hobbed axle;
  • DIN 439 M12 nut;
  • angle grinder with 1mm thick cutter disc;
  • hammer;
  • DIN 1587 M6 nut as a flare-fitter.

I cut 3 lines on one side of a nut that slightly crosses thread.
Then screw in hobbed axle to desired depth.
Cut it to be not higher then 1mm on top of the nut.
Flare-fit inside axle with spherical surface of DIN 1586 nut (you can use any tool that is capable of flare-fitting 8mm inner diameter tube).

This way, aluminium of outside of hobbed axle gets into grooves on the nut, so they become coupled.

Pre-assembling

Nuts should be placed in locks (M3 for motor drive gear and clamp plate, M2 for clamp plate fixer axle). Where needed, use soldering iron.

Hobbed bolts/axles should fit in gears really tight to decrease backlash, so if it not fit completely for the first time, don't drill it with 12mm bit, just move it back and forth few times. It'll do.

All bearings and 608 bearing rods should fit tightly. It's ok. Just make sure not to delaminate 608 bearing inner race support.

Assembling

Motor with driven gear attached should be placed after big driven gear.
Fix motor with M3 bolts, but not completely to allow its movement.
Then push it slightly down, towards hotend slot and tighten M3 bolts.
Make sure that big gear and driven gear on motor spins freely but with no backlash.

Extruder body designed to hold hotend really tight, so hotend fixing bolts should screw in with sensible resistance. If they not, just cut the circle size of hotend base out of any regular sheet of paper, make hole for filament in the center and put it between hotend end extruder body.
Thickness of a paper is about 0.1mm so, if it is still not enough, feel free to repeat as needed.
If bolts are too tight or not fit in in the first place, drill the holes few more times with 3mm bit. Every pass will cut about 0.1mm.

If you want to open the assembled extruder, just push the latch down a little, turn fixing axle away and pull latch up.
This way you can save your exact tension setting when assembling extruder back.

Tensioning

When extruder is assembled and in place, heat it, load the filament and fix clamp plate with a latch to up to 3/4 of latch travel, than fix latch with fixer axle.
Try to extrude some filament. You don't need much, just about 50mm. Then open extruder and take off the filament.
Check notches from hobbed axles on both sides of a filament wire.
They should be equal.
If row of a notches from lower axle deeper than those from upper, you should tight clamp plate harder. Otherwise, you should relax it a little.
After making them even, calibrate the extruder.
For me it is 885 steps per unit for extruder on 230C @ 100mm/min.

This is my butterfly bottle opener - the cooler way to open your Drinks!

I printed with PLA and my "fast-print" 0,6mm nozzle with 0,5mm layer height.
smaller nozzles and layer height will work also with nicer surfaces, but will last in longer print durations.
On the pictures you can see the prototype and it survived the first birthday party where it did a great job.
Tip:
A high infill percentage for the opener will extend the lifetime of the part.
And a higher weight will let the butterfly open mechanism go smoother.

You Need 2x grip and 1x opener.
Screw the parts together with M5 screws and lock-nuts (or put some glue to the nuts).
Stick a euro-cent to the slot in the opener - and there you have it!

I'd like to see your makes!
Suggestions, feedback - let me know in comments.

The head of the opener was inspired by 3dprintler's 3D Printable Bottle Opener
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:191871
which is under creative commons - attribution - non commercial license also.

I changed some things e. g. euro-cent fits in the slot, and of course extend it to match my butterfly design.

Rugose coral (Coelenterata/Rugosa), also known as Horn Coral, from the Devonian of Ontario. The rugose corals all went extinct at the end of the Paleozoic Scanned in Dr. Franek Hasiuk's GeoFabLab (Department of Geological and Atmospheric Sciences, Iowa State University).
Scan Specifications: Scanned with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner set on "medium".

Just insert it on the back motor, and you are done!

easy to put in, stay firmly in place but easy to remove using your thumb against the motor, it is ideal for transporting your multicopter with the gimbal fixed on it without having it moving arround and eventually damage some cables.

I designed it for my xiaomi yi adapter (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1612828), but it should also fit the stock gopro HERO4 adapter.

Notes:

2 or 3 perif are both valid.
I recommend less than 0.2 Z pitch.

smooth finish

making the surface smooth can help the insertion.
polish it gently with sandpaper (#300-600) for a better result, then aceton sauna @ 90deg C for about 5 min.
let it dry without touching it for a dozen hours and you should be good.

comments.text: For everyone printing this item. Acetone treatment is a must for this item. thought I could do without it but I was wrong. broke on first use as the clips easily brake off very soft and breakable. Well lesson learnt. reprinting and went to hardware store to get some acetone.

Yes aceton helps to bond the layers together strongly.
You can also print it at a slightly higher temperature, it will create stronger bonding.
After the aceton sauna treatment, wait at least 24 hours before applying strong force on it.

title: It Doesn't Have to Look Like Raspberry Pi B+, 2B, 3 Case

description.text:
A lot of people liked my "It Doesn't Have to Look Like Raspberry Pi Zero Case" [http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1581003], so I thought I'd try making one for the B+, 2B and 3 Pi's.

I did not realize it would turn out so HUGE!!
You can see it's relative size next to the Pi Zero case in the second photo, it is massive.
Still, it only takes around 25m of filament to print.

One of the reasons it is so tall is to make room at the bottom for the Enthernet and USB cables you might want to plug in.

Pi slides in from underneath and is held in place by friction and/or the power plug. And, again, with the chimney effect, it should help with airflow/cooling.

So, if you want something that looks...well, different sitting on your desk (or elsewhere) housing your Raspberry Pi Media Center, Gateway, IoT device, etc, maybe this is the case for you.

If nothing else, you'll get comments like "WTF is that?!?!?"

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

JG Aurora A3 Prusa I3

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

15-100%

Notes:

Infill doesn't really matter. Most walls are 2-3mm thick. 100% Infill adds about 5m to the print.

No need for supports - that's why the front/back faces are curved at the bottom. But you may get some slight drooping.

I highly recommend a Raft, as the base is very narrow and you don't want it coming off mid-print - or the pointy tips curling up.

Nasty Little Hairs

You'll probably get nasty little hairs inside unless you have one of those really nice printers and slicers. So clean them out with a small file before inserting your Pi. It will be a snug fit, but will loosen with use.

Also, make sure the Pi fits in the little slots at the top of the case.

description.text: customized with 3D Slash!

Le rotor de Savonius est une éolienne à axe vertical. Elle a été inventée par l'ingénieur finlandais Sigurd Savonius en 1924 et a été brevetée en 1929.

Le type Savonius, constitué schématiquement de deux ou plusieurs godets demi-cylindriques légèrement désaxés présente un grand nombre d'avantages. Outre son faible encombrement, qui permet d’intégrer l’éolienne aux bâtiments sans en dénaturer l’esthétique, il est peu bruyant. Il démarre à de faibles vitesses de vent et présente un couple élevé quoique variant de façon sinusoïdale au cours de la rotation. L’accroissement important de la masse en fonction de la dimension rend l’éolienne de type Savonius peu adaptée à la production de masse dans un parc à éoliennes.

description.text: This is a design from years ago when I was in school in an FEA class.  It was meant to be machined from stainless steel 316 but that doesn't mean we can't print it in plastic to play around with it.  Obviously don't actually try to climb a wall with this.  Use at your own risk....etc...

I printed the base vertically upside down to reduce support material use.  When designing it for steel I I did load analysis for the worst case situation of loading at the tip with a 200lb load on it.  
I printed it in pla and found it brittle when I tossed it with the arms open (broke one).  Next time I'll try some other material probably ABS.

comments.text: Pretty Neat!  We could have used this at Holden Village to climb through the mine shaft...or to further rip down the ceiling in the room we stayed in!

title: Vertical X axis for Mendel Max 1.5 Lulzbot style with CNC MOTOR HOLDER (NEW!) and anti-wobbling

description.text:
UPD5. Well thats not so bad. I updated Configuration.h in my Marlin firmware and it has full 180x180 plate space now. I also turned my head 180º and it works ok. You should not tighten linear ball bearings too much to keep smooth movement. Use Kalashnikov AK-47 design principle and loosen everything you can.
and NOW INTRODUCING CNC HOLDER ATTACHMENT. It consists of 2 parts for easy printing. Assemble it with M3 screws. It should clip on existing head but i made a lot of holes to make it hard and steady. CN Holder should accept Epson RS445PA14233-B motor (from broken printer) but any 33mm diameter motor should fit. Go play with it!
TIP: MeshCAM generates suitable GCODE (for CURA) with TurboCNC V3 profile.
UPD4: You should know that this construction is not good at all. After assembly we see that z carets jumping, lower rod may heat from bed and heads while upper stay cold. And you'll have 66 mm less Y-space. Now i really feel horisontal X Axis is better. Check my other projects http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1596991 it really works.
UPD3: Added head holder and servo mount. Belt is T2.5. Now you can mount 3 30mm fans to cool down Chimera (print Verticalx-fanfront.stl three times for that). Which is so hot when you use 2 filaments together.
Chimera is mounted backwards so you can easily unscrew heads.
UPD2: Added motor part.
UPD1: BEWARE! I tried printing it and bearings won't fit. Fixing & testing right now

A summary of 2 projects.
Print this to make vertical x axis.
I use servo for bed levelling, so there's holder for that.
Ball bearings, belts and nuts are standard to Mendel Max, just disassemble your existing x axis.
LM8UU x 4
LM10UU x 4
608ZZ x 1
M6 nut x 4
M6 screw x 1
30mm fan x 1-3
M3 screws x a lot
Nylon straps x 8
Other files on remix source: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:800848 (not needed with update but should be compatible)
De-wobble feature is experimental, don't blame me if this not works

remixed_from.title: Layer cooling fan duct for Da Vinci 1.0 3D printer with the E3Dv6 mod

title: 40mm Fan Shroud Remix DaVinci 1.0A with E3Dv6 Extruder Mod

description.text:
This has been modified from the original (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:822476) to address several issues I had:

  1. My extruder nozzles are Stainless Steel and are several mm longer than the originals from E3D. So the fan was actually blowing on the heater block, and not the layer. I have moved the tip down 5 degrees to actually blow on the layer.
  2. The slots on the original are not in the correct position; even when filed, the belt scrapes against it. Also, I think the belt occasionally hangs on it, causing X-Y failures in print. To get rid of this problem altogether and make it easier to install, I replaced the slots with a semi-circular indentation. This also directed ALL of the fan flow out of the nozzle with no loss.
  3. The holes are for a 50mm fan; I wanted to use the original 40mm, 5v fans from the DaVinci so I could control it with Repetier .92. So I moved the hole slots to install 40mm fan (NOTE: These holes were just 'eye-balled', some drilling/aligning screws may be necessary).
  4. The entire setup was about 5% too large to fit in my DaVinci housing. I reduced it so the block that holds it in is the correct size: 19mmx35mm.

This isn't pretty (modified in mesh lab), but it now works in my DaVinci 1.0A; feel free to drop me a comment!

Be sure to "Like" my Facebook page at https://www.facebook.com/FetalReproductions to subscribe to my current prints/blogs, and see my Etsy page at http://Etsy.com/FetalReproductions for baby fetal scans, skulls, and other items to own.

description.text:
This is a simple ring and peg system to allow linking together any number of crystal light plastic containers. The containers are handy, but get disorganized easily. This prints a ring that goes around the container. The ring has holes on all four sides, and the associated peg perfectly connects any two rings. There is no limit to the size of the array of containers you can put together.

I uses a hex-shaped peg and a round hole, which makes a pretty tight fit. Also, the rings fit fairly tightly around the containers, so everything is just push together. However, a little bit of glue would make it all much more permanent.

For the customizer, you can choose whether to print 0, 1, 2, 3 or 4 pegs along with the ring. I also inclued a "peg.stl" file that you can use if you want to print only a peg and no ring.

NOTE: The Crystal Light containers I have are all exactly 2.0 x 2.5 inches. If you are in an area where they are a different size, you can modify the .scad file fairly easily.
